context: Chickens raised intensively for their meat are known as "<b5_0>broilers<b5_0/>". Breeds have been developed that can grow to an acceptable <a0_0>carcass size (2 kg (4.4 lb))<a0_0/> in <a1_0>six weeks or less<a1_0/>. Broilers grow so fast, <a3_0><b8_0>their legs cannot always support their weight and their hearts and respiratory systems may not be able to supply enough oxygen to their developing muscles<b8_0/>.<a3_0/> <a2_0><b7_0>Mortality rates at 1%<b7_0/><a2_0/> are much higher than for less-intensively reared laying birds which take <a4_0><b6_0>18 weeks<b6_0/> to reach similar weights<a4_0/>. Processing the birds is done automatically with conveyor-belt efficiency. They are <b9_0>hung by their feet, stunned, killed, bled, scalded, plucked, have their heads and feet removed, eviscerated, washed, chilled, drained, weighed, and packed<b9_0/>, all within the course of little over two hours.
